name: Congressman Richard Hudson
subject: Congressman Tracks Down Medal For Moore County Woman Whose Brother Died in WWII
body: Congressman Richard Hudson, 8th District of North Carolina *"If there are other families in the community who are looking for medals that have been lost, they ought to contact our office [link 1]," *said Rep. Richard Hudson, who represents both Moore County and Fort Bragg.* "That's part of the service we provide."* *Congressman Tracks Down Medal For Moore County Woman Whose Brother Died in WWII* [link 2] *The Pilot* By: JAYMIE BAXLEY October 7, 2019 Jean Brady was only 8 years old when her brother died in Germany during World War II. A 19-year-old with the 89th infantry division, Pfc. Raymond Vick mailed his final letter to his family in Nash County on March 26, 1945. He was killed in action that same day. Brady now lives in West End, where she keeps a collection of artifacts from her brother's short life. She has wanted for years to find a pair of military decorations awarded to Vick after his death. Following a conversation with Brady, U.S. Rep. Richard Hudson offered to have his staff track down Vick's missing World War II Victory Medal, along with the late infantryman's lapel pin for honorable service. The decorations had been lost for nearly 75 years. [image = Rep. Richard Hudson (NC-08) presents the lost WWII medal to Jean Brady at American Legion Post No. 12 in Carthage. Last week, one of Hudson's aides contacted Brady with good news. "When his office called and told me they had (my brother's) medal, I was so excited I was bouncing off the wall," Brady said. Hudson presented the recovered awards to Brady during a brief ceremony Monday in front of American Legion Post No. 12 in Carthage. Hudson said his staff had to clear "a lot of red tape" to obtain the decorations, but the process itself was "not tremendously hard." [image = Rep. Hudson presents Mrs. Brady with Pfc. Vick's WWII Victory Medal and lapel pin for honorable service. "If there are other families in the community who are looking for medals that have been lost, they ought to contact our office," said Hudson, who represents both Moore County and Fort Bragg. "That's part of the service we provide." [image = A framed photograph of Pfc. Vick, Mrs. Brady's brother who was KIA in WWII. Hudson said ceremonies like the one held in Carthage are "important because we're losing so many of our World War II veterans every day." "Our younger generation needs to hear those stories," he said. "They need to know who these men were and what they did, and that's why I made a special effort today to be here and do this." ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 2112 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-3715 | Fax: (202) 225-4036 Hours: M-F 8:30am-6:00pm Concord Office 325 McGill Avenue, NW, Suite 500 Concord, NC 28027 Phone: (704) 786-1612 Fax: (704) 782-1004 Hours: M-F 8:30am-5:30pm Fayetteville Office 225 Green Street, Suite 202 Fayetteville, NC 28301 Phone: (910) 997-2070 Fax: (910) 817-7202 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30-5:30pm and by appointment Pinehurst Office Sandhills Community College Logan Building 3395 Airport Road, Suite 221 Pinehurst, NC 28374 (910) 246-5374 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30am-5:30pm and by appointment Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

name: Congressman Richard Hudson
subject: We're all getting older
body: Congressman Richard Hudson, 8th District of North Carolina *Friends, * *We are all getting older. *There are no ifs, ands or buts about it. People say with age comes more wisdom and more kindness - and a lot of wrinkles and grey hair.* As the stories we tell our kids get longer and longer, our memories get shorter and shorter. *But as a famous American architect once said, "The longer I live, the more beautiful life becomes." *Every day, I make it a top priority to ensure our nation's elderly and veterans are cared for.* I have worked tirelessly to protect Social Security and Medicare for our current seniors while strengthening it for future generations. I've worked to lower drug costs at the pharmacy counter and I am committed to ensuring you can access affordable, high-quality health care. *I have consistently been recognized as a "Guardian of Seniors' Rights" by leading seniors' groups for my work to keep our promises to today's seniors and future generations while cutting wasteful government spending.* I continue to fight for reforms to save your tax dollars over the long term and pave the way for a Medicare system that promotes higher quality care for seniors while strengthening the doctor-patient relationship. Last year, I was proud to support the *Strengthening Protections for Social Security Beneficiaries Act of 2017* (H.R. 4547) to improve protections for the millions of Social Security beneficiaries who rely on a representative payee to administer their monthly benefits. *President Donald Trump signed the bill into law, and we've made good progress, but there is still much more work to do.* I'm glad to see this Administration continue to put caring for our nation's seniors at the top of the to-do list. [image = President Donald Trump signed an Executive Order to strengthen Medicare. *On October 3, President Trump doubled down on that commitment by issuing an executive order to protect and improve Medicare for our nation's seniors. *In his announcement, President Trump said he will continue to build on aspects of the program that work well, including the market-based approaches in the current system. The executive order will allow seniors more choices to pick a plan that fits their needs. Additionally, it will eliminate excessive billing requirements and allow doctors to spend more time with patients. *By doing this, we will help empower patients to select and access the right care, at the right time, in the right place, from the right provider.* As a nation, another promise we've made is to honor the service and sacrifice of our nation's service members.* Last week I was fortunate enough to honor a World War II soldier and present his sister the awards he earned in service. *Private First Class (PFC) Raymond Vick was killed in action in Worms, Germany during WWII when his sister, Jean Brady, was just 8 years old. I was able to track down his WWII Victory Medal and the WWII Honorable Service Lapel Pin after they were lost for 74 years. [image = Presenting PFC Vick's WWII medal to his sister, Jean. *The ceremony took place in Carthage where I was blessed with the opportunity to present these awards to his sister. *PFC Vick was born in Nash County in November 1924. He enlisted in the U.S. Army in 1943 in the Infantry. He served in General George Patton's 3rd Army as a member of A company, 355th Infantry Regiment, 89th Infantry Division. He was only 21 years old at the time of his death on March 26, 1945. *As your Congressman, I stand ready to ensure our country keeps the promises made to senior citizens and veterans.* *Until next week,* * [image = *Richard Hudson* *Member of Congress (NC-08)* [image = [link 1] [image = [link 2] [image = [link 3] [image = [link 4] [image = [link 5] [image = [link 6] [image = [link 7] [image = [link 8] ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 2112 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-3715 | Fax: (202) 225-4036 Hours: M-F 8:30am-6:00pm Concord Office 325 McGill Avenue, NW, Suite 500 Concord, NC 28027 Phone: (704) 786-1612 Fax: (704) 782-1004 Hours: M-F 8:30am-5:30pm Fayetteville Office 225 Green Street, Suite 202 Fayetteville, NC 28301 Phone: (910) 997-2070 Fax: (910) 817-7202 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30-5:30pm and by appointment Pinehurst Office Sandhills Community College Logan Building 3395 Airport Road, Suite 221 Pinehurst, NC 28374 (910) 246-5374 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30am-5:30pm and by appointment Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }     p { margin-bottom:1em }          News from Congressman Steve Cohen                             Website | Serving You | Legislative Work | Our District | Resources               October 11, 2019       Dear Friend, This week, I applauded the decision to hold a public hearing in Memphis on the bad idea to block grant Tennessee’s Medicaid program. TennCare did not originally schedule a hearing in our city, despite the disproportionate impact this proposed change would have on Memphians. I also called attention to a roundtable discussion on “Complete Streets” I have scheduled for October 25 to discuss pedestrian, bicyclist and transit users’ safety; expressed concern at the Trump Administration’s stonewalling of legitimate oversight of its clearly impeachable conduct; condemned Trump’s dangerous decision to allow Turkey to invade parts of Syria held by U.S.-backed Kurdish militias; addressed Mr. Rakestraw’s A.P. Government class at White Station High School; talked to a large group of Career and Technical Education (CTE) students at Cordova High School; spoke out against gun violence at a “Moms Demand Action” event; offered 2020 U.S. Historical Society calendars; and offered a health tip on depression. Keep reading to learn more about my week and follow me on Twitter, Facebook and Instagram to see more updates as they happen.   Applauding Decision to Hold a Memphis Public Hearing on Bad TennCare Block Grant Proposal  Holding a Complete Streets Roundtable October 25  Expressing Concern at Trump Administration Stonewalling of the Ukraine-centered Impeachment Inquiry  Condemning Trump’s “Green Light” to Turkey’s Invasion of Syria  Addressing Mr. Rakestraw’s White Station High A.P. Government Class  Talking to Career and Technical Education Students at Cordova High   Speaking Out Against Gun Violence at a “Moms Demand Action” Event  Offering 2020 U.S. Historical Society Calendars  Weekly Health Tip  Quote of the Week    Applauding Decision to Hold a Memphis Public Hearing on Bad TennCare Block Grant Proposal   I wrote to Governor Bill Lee on September 20 requesting a public hearing on the TennCare Block Grant proposal. Shelby County has more than ten times the number of beneficiaries as Madison County, the only county in West Tennessee originally scheduled for a public hearing. I also wrote an op-ed for The Commercial Appeal. I am pleased to see a hearing has been planned for Tuesday, October 15, at 1:30 p.m. at the University Center Ballroom, 499 University Street. Memphians deserve to be heard.  This proposal would allow the state government to arbitrarily change TennCare coverage and slash benefits for those who need them most. I hope the hearing is well-attended and expect it to produce the overwhelmingly negative response it has already received at hearings in Knoxville, Nashville and Jackson.   Holding a Complete Streets Roundtable October 25     Congressman Cohen speaking at People for Bikes Workshop Thursday  It is an unpleasant fact that Memphis has a reputation as one of the most dangerous cities for pedestrians, bicyclists and users of public transit. That’s why I introduced H.R. 3663, the Complete Streets Act. This bill would create a program to pay for technical assistance and provide capital grants for projects such as sidewalks, bike lanes and bus stops to improve the safety and efficiency of transit. I am hosting a Complete Streets roundtable discussion on October 25 in Memphis to hear ideas from private sector stakeholders and our local, state and federal government on how to produce safer Complete Streets. On Thursday, I attended a City of Memphis and People for Bikes workshop at which protected bike lane proponents, such as keynote speaker Charles T. Brown of Rutgers University, spoke of transportation equity and the need to prioritize the interests of pedestrians and bicyclists after decades of prioritizing moving as many cars as possible through our streets.  Expressing Concern at Trump Administration Stonewalling of Ukraine Impeachment Inquiry   Just as Trump has repeatedly stonewalled the House Judiciary Committee throughout the 116th Congress, he is now obstructing the House’s impeachment inquiry into his attempts to pressure foreign governments to dig up dirt on his political opponents. The American people deserve answers and it is essential we stand up to this President’s reckless and impeachable behavior. See my interview about the ongoing stonewalling with CNN’s Bianna Keilar here and with CNN’s Jim Sciutto here.  Condemning Trump’s Irresponsible “Green Light” to Turkey’s Invasion of Syria   I am deeply disappointed in the President’s knee-jerk and irresponsible decision to give Turkey the green light to invade parts of northeastern Syria currently occupied by U.S.-backed Kurdish militias. There has been a bipartisan chorus from lawmakers and foreign policy experts condemning the President’s decision to abandon an important ally. I am also very concerned about what message this abandonment sends to our other allies. I dread the humanitarian disaster that likely comes next.     Addressing Mr. Rakestraw’s White Station High School A.P. Government Class    On Tuesday, I met with students in teacher Curt Rakestraw’s Advanced Placement Government class at White Station High School to talk about what I’m doing in Congress and to take thoughtful questions from students. Mr. Rakestraw is clearly a great teacher and his engaging students are a testament to his hard work. It was an honor to meet with them.   Talking to Career and Technical Education Students at Cordova High School    On Thursday, I met with more than 650 juniors and seniors in various Career and Technical Education (CTE) programs at Cordova High School about the importance of Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) programs. As a member of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, I have supported legislation to expand access to these essential programs. Just last month, the House passed the STEM Opportunities Act to remove barriers for minority students in STEM fields. It is essential that our best and brightest have to opportunity to conduct research and improve technology to make us all safer, healthier and better prepared to meet the challenges ahead. I want to thank Principal Barton Thorne, teacher Ariane Kavass and the entire “Wolfpack” for inviting me.  Speaking Out Against Gun Violence at a “Moms Demand Action” Event      On Thursday, I joined “Moms Demand Action” volunteers to speak out against senseless gun violence. The Judiciary Committee on which I serve as a senior member has passed a red flag law and limits on high-capacity magazines while the whole House has passed a bipartisan universal background checks bill and a bill closing the Charleston loophole. Unfortunately, these measures remain bottled up by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell who cares more about the NRA than the safety of our communities.    Offering 2020 U.S. Historical Society Calendars    My office will have a limited number of 2020 U.S. Capitol Historical Society calendars available. If you would like to receive a calendar, please complete  on my website. Due to the rules of the House, I am only able to mail calendars to residents of Tennessee’s Ninth District. Please feel free to share this email with other residents of the Ninth District who may be interested in receiving one but who do not receive my e-Newsletter.     Sign Up for “Congress on Your Corner” and this e-Newsletter         I enjoy meeting regularly with constituents in the district and helping get answers for them to questions about dealing with federal agencies. If you are interested in attending one of my “Congress on Your Corner” events, you can sign up here to receive a notification as soon as the next event is scheduled. My next “Congress on Your Corner” is Friday, October 25, from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m., at the South Branch Library, 1929 South Third Street, Memphis 38109.       For those who haven’t participated in a telephone town hall, it’s easy to sign up for them by using this form.         If you would like to receive this weekly e-Newsletter, or share it with others, you can do that with this form.    Weekly Health Tip     Depression affects more than 8.1 percent of adults over 20 and can be a torment endured in silence without professional intervention. Depression among women is about twice as common as among men. Thursday was National Depression Screening Day, but any day when you or a loved one feel desperate or depressed is a good day to seek help. The National Suicide Prevention Hotline is available 24/7 at 1-800-273-8255. See some guidance and resources from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention here.    Quote of the Week     “If you were really great and powerful, you’d keep your promises!” – Dorothy Gale, played by Judy Garland, to the Wizard, played by Frank Morgan, in “The Wizard of Oz” (1939)   As always, I remainMost Sincerely,   Steve CohenMember of Congress                  Memphis 167 North Main Street,Suite 369Memphis, TN 38103Phone: (901) 544-4131Fax: (901) 544-4329 Washington, D.C. 2104 RayburnHouse Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-3265Fax: (202) 225-5663                     Unsubscribe | Private Policy

The actions by President Erdoğan and the Turkish forces has brought increased violence and instability to a vitally important region. That is why I am co-sponsoring Congresswoman Liz Cheney's bill to increase sanctions on Turkey in response to their invasion of Syria. I was also asked about hemp farming and what can be done to help foster its growth here in Virginia.  I was proud to say that I lead the delegation in sending a letter to the USDA to have Virginia included as a one of the states where hemp growers will now be eligible to receive crop insurance.   I am grateful for everyone who was able to make it to the town hall. For updates on future town halls please check back   If you need help with a federal agency please contact my Charlottesville Office at (434) 973-9631 or see my staff during our mobile office hours on Tuesday's across the 5th District.  If you would like to schedule a tour of either the Capitol, or another federal building in Washington, including the White House or the FBI please contact our Washington D.C. office at (202) 225-4711.   Sincerely,  Member of Congress Denver in the News  Cline, Riggleman hold town hall in Bedford  Cline, Riggleman Bemoan Hyper-Partisanship During Joint Town Hall Meeting  Congressman Riggleman, Cline to hold joint town hall with in Bedford  For parents only: Practical advice on risky behaviors  Greene Commons opens: Community, dignitaries celebrate completion of new space  Mobile Office Hours  Mobile office hours will be held on Tuesday, October 15, 2019.  Constituents are invited to meet with a representative of the office in Appomattox County, Bedford County, Campbell County, Cumberland County, and Nelson County.   These office hours offer constituents the opportunity to meet with the Congressman’s staff in their communities and receive assistance with issues involving federal agencies.  Staff will be available to assist and answer questions regarding Social Security benefits, Medicare, immigration, veterans benefits, and more.  All are encouraged to attend.  Appomattox County:   Time: 12:30 - Iran says missiles struck one of its oil tankers in the Red Sea The Washington Post Missiles struck an Iranian oil tanker off the coast of Saudi Arabia on Friday, Iran’s state news agency reported, damaging the ship’s hull and spilling oil into the Red Sea.  Advocates Try To Help Migrants Navigate Trump's Public Charge Rule NPR The Trump administration's new public charge rule, which makes it more difficult for immigrants to get green cards if it looks like they might need public assistance, is set to go into effect on Oct. 15. Multiple groups, including several states and immigrants' rights advocates, are in court trying to delay the rule and ultimately block it. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                                                                   Dear Friend,  Thank you for your message regarding H.R. 763, the Energy Innovation and Carbon Dividend Act. Your concerns are my highest priority when developing policies that seek to meet the needs of the district. It is undeniable that the effects of climate change are felt by communities throughout the world. Major hurricanes, including Harvey and Dorian, are representative of the impact climate change has had in the United States. Additionally, wild fires on the west coast threaten the safety of Americans. Reading through your concerns, I am reminded of Congress’s need to act swiftly on the effects of climate change because our actions will determine the future of the world. The House passed H.R. 9, the Climate Action Now Act, which aims to keep the United States in the 2015 Paris Climate Agreement. This is the first time in the past decade that a climate bill has made it through the House. However, our efforts to limit the impact of climate change must continue. I am taking prudent steps to mitigate the impacts experienced by communities most at risk.  Throughout past sessions, I have fought to pass bills that seek to protect the environment and increase funding for research. Congress passed bills I have authored including H.R. 1157, the Breast Cancer and Environmental Research Act of 2008, which made grants to conduct collaborative multidisciplinary and multi-institutional research on environmental factors that may be related to the etiology of breast cancer, and H.R. 2494, the Eliminate, Neutralize, and Disrupt Wildlife Trafficking Act of 2016, which addresses wildlife trafficking, which is the poaching or other illegal taking of protected or managed species and the illegal trade in wildlife and their related parts and products. Moving forward, I am driven to promote reforestation efforts and develop green spaces in urban areas that will not create problematic impacts on these communities. Addressing the effects of climate change are not actions that should solely be taken by Congress. State and local governments must hold themselves accountable to ensure we are limiting these effects. The City of Houston has taken ambitious steps through the Climate Action Plan. It provides evidenced-based measures to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and preventative measures to address the negative outcomes of climate change. The plan will demonstrate how the City will adapt and improve its resilience to climate hazards that impact the city today as well as risks that may increase in the coming years. To comply with the Paris Climate Accord, Houston’s plan will follow science-based criteria that will cap the temperature increases associated with climate change to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Scientists believe that preventing global temperatures from rising more than 1.5 degrees Celsius will avert the worst consequences of climate change. This plan will create ambitious targets to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and establish a pathway to meet the Paris Agreement goal of becoming carbon neutral by 2050. After three major floods with the largest rain event in North American history, climate change is an unprecedented challenge for Houston. Sustainability and resiliency go hand-in-hand and this plan is essential to the health and economic vitality of Houston’s future. Developing a Climate Action Plan allows the City to develop strategies that will not only help minimize the City’s carbon footprint but can help save money and improve the quality of life of residents. The benefits associated with climate action planning include decreased traffic and congestion, improved air quality, better access to parks and green spaces, and cost savings through energy efficiency projects.  The effects of climate change are strongly related to economic, public health, and economic issues. Congress should address these issues for the safety of future generations. As the energy capital of the world, Houston must develop bold strategies to implement sustainable energy efforts. In the current session, I have cosponsored five bills related to limiting the impacts of climate change. These bills include H.R. 1429, the Drinking Water Infrastructure for Job Creation Act; H.R. 2748, the SAFE Act Safeguarding America's Future and Environment Act; H.R. 852, the Get the Lead Out of Schools Act; H.R. 1337, Saving America's Pollinators Act of 2019; and H.R. 1137, the Environmental Health Workforce Act of 2019. These are initial but monumental steps I have taken to ensure that your concerns as residents of the 18th Congressional District are addressed. I will continue to consider climate bills as they move through the legislative process, including H.R. 763. Your input is vital to ensure that we hold government entities accountable in responding to the effects of climate change.  Thank you,   Shelia Jackson LeeMember of Congress                      Washington DC Office 2187 Rayburn HOBWashington, DC 20515phone: (202) 225-3816fax: (202) 225-3317hours: M-F 9-6:00 pm Acres Office6719 West MontgomerySuite 204Houston, TX 77091phone: (713) 691-4882fax: (713) 655-1612  Fifth Ward Office4300 Lyons Ave.Houston, TX 77020phone: (713) 227-7740fax: (713) 227-7707  Heights Office 420 West 19th StreetHouston, TX 77008phone: (713) 861-4070fax: (713) 861-4323  Houston Main Office 1919 Smith Street Suite 1180Houston, TX 77002phone: (713) 655-0050fax: (713) 655-1612hours: M-F 9-6:00 pm          MAKE APPOINTMENT WITH HOUSTON MAIN OFFICE FOR SATELLITE OFFICE APPOINTMENTS      Unsubscribe | Privacy Policy

line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }                 If you are having trouble viewing this email, please view it on my website.                                        Kansans in the Office   Carl Brandt of Overland ParkNancy Brant of Overland ParkBen Overesch of Overland ParkCarly Overesch of Overland Park American Veterinary Medical Association Dr. Cary Christensen of Overland ParkDr. Garry Cowan of WichitaLibby Schneider of Logan Capitol Tour Marilyn Claussen of AlmaVerne Claussen of AlmaJoe Grasela of LeavenworthJoseph Grasela of LeavenworthMaggie Keenan of LeawoodMatt Keenan of LeawoodMary Leigh Myers of DeliaRod Manges of ManhattanShelley Manges of ManhattanTylor Provine of Manhattan FCCLA State Executive Council Ella Burrows of SatantaKarlyn Gustin of AuburnBrooke Nafziger of GoesselJerry Stuckey of MoscowJudy Stuckey of Satanta Kansas Principal of the Year Principal Greg Rosenhagen of Cheney Midwest Transplant Network Jan Finn of WestwoodSalama Gallimore of Westwood MOARC and Kansas City Council Mike Lally of Overland ParkTerry Leeds of Overland ParkTom Poer of Overland ParkTom Roberts of Overland Park                                                                                                                                                                 Kansas Common Sense October 7, 2019  Hello, Welcome to “Kansas Common Sense.” Thanks for your continued interest in receiving my weekly newsletter. Please feel free to forward it on to your family and friends if it would interest them. Working to Support Kansas Law Enforcement Inviting Attorney General William Barr to Kansas On Wednesday, I hosted Attorney General William Barr to tour key facilities in Topeka and Wichita and to meet with state and local law enforcement. In Topeka, we visited the Kansas Intelligence Fusion Center and the Kansas Bureau of Investigation’s Forensic Science Center. Both facilities work in partnership with agencies and jurisdictions throughout Kansas, and we heard an update on their work to assist law enforcement in solving and fighting crime in every corner of the state.   In Wichita we joined staff of the U.S. Attorney’s office to discuss ongoing partnerships to fight and prosecute crime and met with folks at Wichita State University engaged in work between the university’s Law Enforcement Training Center and the ATF. Both components in Topeka and Wichita are vital to Kansans and to the professionals who work to protect our communities. Most importantly, in both Topeka and Wichita, we spent time with law enforcement officials to hear firsthand how we can best support them at the federal level.   As the chief appropriator of the Department of Justice, I’m committed to working with Attorney General Barr to make certain our law enforcement personnel have the tools they need to do their jobs and keep communities safe across Kansas and the country. An essential part of keeping our communities safe is creating partnerships between federal, state and local law enforcement to accomplish their mission.   I’m proud of the work we’ve seen from all across the state to increase collaboration for the safety and well-being of Kansans. Attorney General Barr has a deep appreciation for our men and women in uniform, and I thank him for meeting with Kansas law enforcement during his time in our state.  Photo by Jaime Green of the Wichita Eagle.  Announcing the Reopening of DEA’s Garden City Office On Monday morning I joined officials from the Drug Enforcement Administration (DEA), Kansas Bureau of Investigation and the Garden City Police Department to announce the reopening of the Garden City DEA field office. The reopening of this office will enhance efforts by local law enforcement to get drugs off the streets and stop the flow of contraband to the rest of the country. Since its closure in 2017, we’ve worked to demonstrate the region’s need for this office, and through my role as the chief appropriator for the DEA, I’ve worked to make certain there are the necessary resources to complete the reopening. I look forward to seeing the many benefits this office will provide to Southwest Kansas and the entire state. To read more from the Garden City Telegram on this reopening and what it means for the region, click here.   Speaking on the Legacy of President John Bardo at Wichita State On Friday evening, I joined Wichita State University officials and Wichita community leaders to honor the legacy of Dr. John Bardo in the official renaming ceremony of the Experiential Engineering Building to the John Bardo Center. As President of Wichita State University, Dr. Bardo led a period of unprecedented growth for the school that spread to the community and the entire region. During my remarks, I noted the significant impact throughout the Wichita State community by Dr. Bardo and expressed my deep gratitude for his service to Wichita.   Autism CARES Act Signed Into Law This week, the president signed the Autism Collaboration, Accountability, Research, Education and Support, or the CARES Act, into law. I am pleased to be a cosponsor of this legislation that is the strongest-ever package of federal support for research, services and training for the autism community. According to the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), autism impacts an estimated 1 in 59 children in the United States, and often comes with lifelong health and quality of life challenges. Additional research funding in this legislation will improve our understanding of autism through research at the National Institutes of Health, the CDC and the Health Resources and Services Administration. Ultimately, through these important investments, we will be able to better care for this unique and vibrant community. Click here to read more on the CARES Act. Celebrating Spirit AeroSystem’s Partnership with Wichita State On Friday, I attended the grand opening of the Spirit AeroSystems Research Collaboration Center which is housed at the Wichita State University (WSU) Innovation Campus. The center establishes a unique partnership between Spirit and the university through the National Institute for Aviation Research (NIAR) and WSU Tech. This partnership will accelerate and enhance Spirit’s research and development objectives as well as applied learning opportunities that better prepare students for the aviation and aerospace industries. As co-chair of the Senate Aerospace Caucus and as a member of the Senate Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense, I look forward to working further with these two exceptional organizations to further solidify Wichita’s place as the Air Capital of the World. Congratulations to all those who made this special occasion possible, and special thanks to Spirit CEO Tom Gentile and WSU Vice President for Research and Technology John Tomblin for their leadership.        Watching the K-State Game On Saturday, I was at Bill Snyder Family Stadium in Manhattan to watch K-State play the Baylor Bears. This week’s game was “Fort Riley Day” and honored the men and women who serve in the 1st Infantry Division and at Fort Riley. The K-State Marching Band paid tribute to those serving our military around the world with a halftime performance that included the military anthems for each branch of the armed forces. During the game, I had the opportunity to visit with good friends Van Witthuhn, Eldon Stoecklein, Pat Parke, Carolyn States and Carol and Eric Hartman. EMAW!   Hosting Kansas Listening Tour Stops Seward County On Monday, I was in Liberal for a stop on my Kansas Listening Tour. During this townhall meeting, I discussed a number of items with folks from Seward County including my work to increase veterans’ access to healthcare through the VA MISSION Act, the need for Congress to pass USMCA, the current farm economy, crop insurance, immigration reform, access to mental healthcare, the need for updated infrastructure, rural broadband and gun violence. Thank you to all those who attended for their productive conversation, and to the Liberal Lions Club for their hospitality.   Meade County On Monday afternoon, I hosted a Kansas Listening Tour stop in Meade County. During this stop, local residents and I discussed a number of issues including healthcare in rural communities, veterans’ access to care, agriculture and the need to pass USMCA for farmers and ranchers, immigration, gun violence, rural broadband and my work to make certain rural America can thrive. Thanks to those from across Meade County for taking time to share their thoughts and ideas with me on Monday. Visiting with Impressive Kansas Students Plains Elementary School Prior to my Meade County Listening Tour stop, I joined students and staff of Plains Elementary School. A special thank you to Plains Elementary School 5th grade students Emilee, Lindanis and Juanluis for the great tour of their school. These bright, curious and passionate students represented PES so well and are a testament to the dedicated and caring teachers in their lives. During our tour, they demonstrated a number of ways students and teachers are employing new and innovative methods of thinking and learning and provided a robust update on their activities and things happening in the community. They also asked impressive and insightful questions on current topics in public policy, matters before the Senate as they relate to their community and even expressed a desire to one day have careers in public service. I was pleased to have the Commissioner of the Kansas State Department of Education, Dr. Randy Watson, along for the tour, as well as State Board of Education member Jean Clifford, USD 483 Superintendent Elton Argo and Principals Ryan Kisner, Dan Frisby and Kurt Stanfield. A special thank you to Bri Frisby for the kind invitation to join these students for the day.   Riley County High School On Thursday, I joined student leaders to tour Riley County High School, home of the Falcons. While touring the school, students and administrators discussed the programs they’ve implemented to prepare students for their next steps in life. Riley County High School’s programming emphasizes both technical education, through numerous agriculture, woodworking, and welding courses, as well as college preparatory programs allowing students to capitalize on their time in school and earn credits towards a college degree. Rural schools across Kansas are working to address the shortage in our state’s workforce by continuing to prioritize STEM education and create career pipelines for students after they graduate.   Newton High School On Friday, I was in Newton where I joined student leaders for a tour of Newton High School. During the tour, I heard updates on fall activities, NHS athletic teams, different things happening in the classroom and new programs and courses. We visited a number of career and technical education-focused classrooms where teachers are working to prepare students for the workforce and various secondary educational paths. My time at Newton High School came just ahead of Department of Education Assistant Secretary Scott Stump’s tour of the high school – specifically geared toward their career and technical education offerings. I know that Mr. Stump will be as impressed as I was with the quality of work, commitment from students and dedication of teachers at Newton High School.   Now Accepting Spring Internship Applications My own interest in public service was sparked by an internship for Kansas First District Congressman Keith Sebelius in 1974. As an intern, I had the chance to learn firsthand how a Congressional office operates and how the legislative process works. I am proud to be able to offer this same opportunity in my Senate office today, where I have interns year-round working closely with my staff on behalf of Kansans. Applications for internships in my Washington, D.C. and Kansas offices for the spring 2020 session are due October 25. Congressional internships are open to qualified undergraduate and graduate students who have an interest in public service and have achieved academic excellence. Click here for more information and to apply.  Honored to Serve You in Washington It is an honor to serve you in Washington, D.C. Thank you to the many Kansans who have been calling and writing in to share their thoughts and opinions on the issues our state and country face. I appreciate the words of Kansans, whether in the form of a form of letter, a Facebook comment or a phone call, who wish to make their voice heard.   Please let me know how I can be of assistance. You can contact me by email by . You can also  to contact me through one of my Kansas offices or my Washington, D.C., office. Very truly yours,Jerry  My email address is only equipped to send messages. I encourage you to send me a message through my website: . To unsubscribe from this newsletter, please . subject: Thank God That Such Men Lived
body: Congressman Richard Hudson, 8th District of North Carolina *Friends,* *As General George S. Patton once said, "It is foolish and wrong to mourn the men who died. Rather we should thank God that such men lived."* I thank God every day for the brave men and women who step up when our country needs them. Last week was a solemn reminder of the sacrifice of these soldiers and their families. October 4, 2019 marked the 2nd Anniversary of the Tongo Tongo ambush in Niger, Africa that injured two and took the lives of four members of the U.S. Army's 3rd Special Forces Group (Airborne): Staff Sergeant Bryan Black, Sergeant La David T. Johnson, Sergeant First Class Jeremiah Johnson, and Staff Sergeant Dustin Wright. *These men paid the ultimate sacrifice and our country can never repay the debt we owe to them and their families.* * [image = Staff Sergeant Black Staff Sergeant Bryan Black, a native of Puyallup, Washington, enlisted in the U.S. Army in September of 2009. *Speaking of Black's sheer determination, his father said, "Some people could, would, should. Other people do. Bryan did."* Over the course of his military career, he earned his Green Beret. He received numerous medals, including the Purple Heart, Meritorious Service Medal and a Bronze Star with Valor. *Perhaps one of his greatest accomplishments and loves of his life were his family: his wife and their two young boys.* [image = Sergeant First Class Johnson Sergeant First Class Jeremiah Johnson, from Springboro, Ohio, enlisted in the United States Army in October of 2007. As a Chemical, Biological Radiological and Nuclear Specialist, he underwent some of the most specialized training in our military and emerged as a leader and role model. *His family and friends described him as "a red, white and blue, rock-solid American with a great heart." *He was awarded various medals including the Purple Heart, Meritorious Service Medal and a Bronze Star Medal with Valor. *He was a beloved son, husband and father and he left behind his wife and two teenage daughters.* * [image = Staff Sergeant Wright Staff Sergeant Dustin Wright, from Lyons, Georgia, enlisted in the Army in July of 2012. He attended Special Forces Assessment and Selection program and he earned his Green Beret. He was the third of four brothers in a family with a strong history of military service. *His brother described him as being "propelled by a sharp sense of duty." *For his service, he received numerous medals, including the Purple Heart, Meritorious Service Medal and posthumous Silver Star Medal. *Despite the tough guy, Green Beret exterior, his friends and family will remember him as "a lovable clown. He was the nicest, most gentle man you ever met."* * [image = Sergeant Johnson Sergeant La David T. Johnson, born in Miami, Florida, enlisted in the Army in January of 2014. After completion of Advanced Individual Training, he earned the Military occupational specialty 91B Wheeled Vehicle Mechanic.* He was highly respected by his teammates, and he rose through the ranks because of his hard work and determination. *He received numerous medals, including the Purple Heart, Meritorious Service Medal and a posthumous Silver Star Medal. While he was an accomplished soldier, he was most proud of his family - his wife, son and two daughters. *As his obituary says, "It was during his early school years that he met his best friend, Myeshia Manual, who would later become his wife."* When our country needed them most, these heroes answered the call to serve our great nation. *The loss of these men left a void for their families and friends that can't be filled, but I continue to pray that God brings peace and comfort.* I will always remember these men, and I thank God they lived.* I will continue do everything in my power to honor their sacrifice, support their teammates and ensure their families are cared for.* *Until next week,* * [image = *Richard Hudson* *Member of Congress (NC-08)* [image = [link 1] [image = [link 2] [image = [link 3] [image = [link 4] [image = [link 5] [image = [link 6] [image = [link 7] [image = [link 8] ---------------------- footnotes ---------------------- [link 1] [link 2] [link 3] [link 4] [link 5] [link 6] [link 7] [link 8] Website: Office Locations: Washington, DC Office 2112 Rayburn House Office Building Washington, DC 20515 Phone: 202-225-3715 | Fax: (202) 225-4036 Hours: M-F 8:30am-6:00pm Concord Office 325 McGill Avenue, NW, Suite 500 Concord, NC 28027 Phone: (704) 786-1612 Fax: (704) 782-1004 Hours: M-F 8:30am-5:30pm Fayetteville Office 225 Green Street, Suite 202 Fayetteville, NC 28301 Phone: (910) 997-2070 Fax: (910) 817-7202 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30-5:30pm and by appointment Pinehurst Office Sandhills Community College Logan Building 3395 Airport Road, Suite 221 Pinehurst, NC 28374 (910) 246-5374 Hours: Tues/Thurs 8:30am-5:30pm and by appointment Privacy Policy: Unsubscribe:

Dear Friend,  You may have missed it amidst all the impeachment hoopla, but President Trump secured another trade victory last week. In a big win for farmers, the United States reached a trade deal with Japan, our third largest agricultural export market. As a result, Japan will reduce tariffs on both fresh and frozen beef and pork. Tariffs will be eliminated or phased out on a multitude of U.S. farm products including several produced in Missouri such as sweet corn, sorghum, ethanol, frozen poultry, processed pork, egg products and wine. The United States, on the other hand, will eliminate or reduce tariffs on several products produced in Japan including green tea, chewing gum, and certain perennial and cut flowers. This is welcome news for U.S consumers. This is a big deal for America. Our farmers will greatly benefit from the U.S.-Japan Trade Agreement, with almost unfettered access to the 127 million consumers in Japan. The more markets available, the better it is for rural Missouri, with increased job growth and the potential for rising farm income. While President Trump is busy securing good trade deals for rural America, Nancy Pelosi still won’t bring the United States-Mexico-Canada agreement to the floor of the House. Impeachment has sucked the oxygen out of the room and nobody in the majority can seem to focus on what’s actually going to help our country. Passing USMCA is a no-brainer and there’s no doubt it will happen if it gets to the House floor. The administration secured a good, free, and fair trade deal and it’s ready to pass. As we all know though, this isn’t about getting a good deal; it’s about denying the President a win. In spite of the clear benefits, I’m willing to bet that if the U.S.-Japan Trade Agreement had been required to come to the House floor, it would still be languishing there as well. Thankfully, Nancy Pelosi didn’t get a say on the Japan deal. It’s been a tough year for farmers. The U.S.-Japan Trade Agreement is certainly welcome news. Now it’s time to bring USMCA to a vote and get it done. North Missouri is counting on it. body: October 2, 2019 Click here if you have trouble viewing this email Op-Ed: Listen to the Kids. Climate Change Must Be Addressed. Rep. Nadler speaking in support of the Green New Deal at a climate change rally in Washington, D.C. Last week, I wrote an op-ed in The Villager calling on Congress and the Administration to tackle the crisis of climate change head-on and improve our nation's climate resilience. To read my full op-ed, please click here. Below is a portion of the op-ed: "Climate change is real and threatens all of us, regardless of nationality, political party, or economic status. Extreme climate change has already arrived in the United States and impacts every congressional district across our country. "In New York City, the potential for stronger storms and rising seas mean Sandy-level flooding could occur once every 23 years as opposed to once every 400. The 2018 National Climate Assessment, a report compiled by 13 federal scientific agencies, warns that we only have a small window of time to take meaningful action to cut carbon emissions if we are to avoid irreversible changes. "Scientists warn that window could close within about a decade if the earth heats up by an average of 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit. If that happens, shrinking glaciers in the poles could lead to a massive sea-level rise, harming the planets ability to recover from further warming. "That metric may seem theoretical, but its not; according to the analysis from The Washington Post, 71 counties have already hit the 3.6 degrees Fahrenheit mark, including all five boroughs. "At a time when America should be leading the global fight against climate change, the Trump Administration has taken our nation backward, recklessly withdrawing us from the Paris Agreement and rolling back countless environmental regulations designed to curb greenhouse-gas emissions." To read my my full op-ed, please click here. body: /* Client-specific Styles */ body { width: 100% !important; margin: 0px;} .ReadMsgBody { width: 100%; } .ExternalClass { width: 100%; display:block !important; } /* Force Hotmail to display emails at full width */ /* Reset Styles */ body { margin:0; padding: 0; } img { outline: none; text-decoration: none; max-width :100%;} br, strong br, b br, em br, i br { line-height: 100%; } h1, h2, h3, h4, h5, h6 { line-height: 100% !important; -webkit-font-smoothing: antialiased; } /*ly, tr#221562, add same margin as margin-block-start/end*/ h1{margin-top:0.67em;margin-bottom:0.67em;} h2{margin-top:0.83em;margin-bottom:0.83em;} h3{margin-top:1em;margin-bottom:1em;} h4{margin-top:1.33em;margin-bottom:1.33em;} h5{margin-top:1.67em;margin-bottom:1.67em;} h6{margin-top:2.33em;margin-bottom:2.33em;} table td, table tr { border-collapse: collapse; } p { margin-bottom: 1em; } table.menu-change a { text-decoration:none; } /* pre-header */ .preheader { display:none !important; visibility:hidden; mso-hide:all !important; font-size:0px; color:#ffffff; line-height:0px; max-height:0px; max-width:0px; opacity:0; overflow:hidden; }      p { margin-bottom:1em; }     News from Representative Payne Jr.                           Serving You  Media Center                 Update from Congressman Payne, Jr.  Dear Friends, Fall is here and it is great to be back to work.  I enjoyed all the events I was able to attend, friends I was able to see, and new residents I was able to meet in the district during the summer recess.  Now that we are back in session, I wanted to update you on the actions I’ve taken, and continue to take, to make life better for all of us in the 10th District.  Presidential Impeachment: Reviewing President Trump's actions in office  My office received dozens of calls from angry constituents who support the impeachment of President Trump after press reports detailed Trump's threat to withhold foreign aid from Ukraine unless President Volodymyr Zelensky conducted a baseless investigation into former Vice President Joe Biden and his son, Hunter.   On September 24th, House Speaker Rep. Nancy Pelosi announced that the House would conduct a full impeachment inquiry of President Trump's actions to determine whether they violate his oath of office.  Personally, I believe there is enough evidence to pursue articles of impeachment against this president already.  But I do fully support this inquiry in order to present the facts, so my House colleagues can reach their own conclusions.  I am proud to be one of the original supporters of Rep. Al Green's resolution, H. Res. 498, which called for the impeachment of President Trump on July 17, 2019.       Newark’s Water Crisis: Providing clean water to Newark's residents  I am extremely concerned about the elevated levels of lead found in Newark’s drinking water.  After all, my family and I drink this water with the rest of the city's residents. The health and safety of constituents is my #1 priority. Right now, my team and I are working with city, state and national officials to help do what needs to be done to get lead out of the water.  But I wanted to see the issue personally, so I volunteered to help my constituents get clean water at two local distribution facilities.  I was grateful to the staff at the Bo Porter Sports Complex and Boylan Street Recreation Center for what they do on a daily basis to help our community.  I enjoyed meeting with my constituents to hear their concerns about this crisis.         Congressman Payne, Jr. chats with residents and helps distribute bottled water.    We talked about their fears of living with tainted water.  I told them what I am doing to help, but also asked them if there were any other actions I could take to make sure a tragedy like this one doesn't happen again. There are many actions I've taken to try and solve the issue.  I introduced the Test for Lead Act in Congress already.  I co-signed and sent two letters: one to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (find it here) to urge them to provide more assistance to Newark and the other to the U.S. Department of Agriculture (find it here) to expand access to SNAP and low-income food subsidies to cover the additional costs of bottled water.   In addition, I’m working with my colleague Rep. Grace Napolitano, chairwoman of the Committee of Transportation and Infrastructure's Subcommittee on Water Resources and the Environment, to find out how we might be able to help the city with federal funding or other resources.  Recently, I voted for legislation in the House that would allow communities the freedom to adjust their budgets to provide additional resources to their water treatment facilities in the event of an emergency.  The legislation passed both U.S. Senate and the U.S. House and it needs President Trump's signature to become law.    I believe federal funds are appropriate because what has happened in Flint, MI. and Newark shows that lead contamination from old pipes are a national concern. There are dozens of major cities and small communities across the country that could use an upgrade regarding the way water gets from the aquifers to the household faucets. If we solve Newark’s water infrastructure issues, we create an example and template we can follow when other cities suffer the same fate. Job Fair for Veterans: Introducing veterans to future employers  More than 100 veterans participated in my annual job fair on August 7th, the largest turnout we’ve had. Next year, we are going to look at larger facilities in our district to attract even more veterans and the companies that want to hire them. I was excited and grateful to give back to the men and women who have given so much to this country.        An Amazon representative discusses a future career with a veteran (8/7/2019)    Disaster Preparation and Emergency Response: Making sure we are prepared before, during and after a crisis  Last July, I wanted to see if our district was prepared to care for the underserved and most vulnerable people of our community during an emergency. We’ve seen how changes in our climate have increased the intensity of hurricanes and other natural disasters across the country. I don’t want what happened in Puerto Rico and New Orleans after they were struck by hurricanes to happen to us.  As chairman of the Subcommittee on Emergency Preparedness, Response and Recovery of the Committee on Homeland Security, I held a hearing on the matter on July 23rd called “Protecting Every Citizen: Assessing Emergency Preparedness for Underserved Populations.” The hearing was held at the Mac Mahon Student Center in Saint Peter’s University in Jersey City, so it could be accessible to my constituents. The hearing gave all of us a better understanding of the needs of underserved or vulnerable populations before, during, and after a crisis. It was extremely informative to hear from researchers, emergency responders, and community groups regarding how we plan for and meet the needs of our most vulnerable citizens before, during and after an emergency.   Increased Manufacturing Base: Creating more manufacturing jobs for New Jersey   No area of our economy has suffered job losses like America’s manufacturing base. In August, I spoke with members of a local Machinists’ union about how we can increase the opportunities for workers affected by these job losses. The event is important because it gives me an opportunity to listen as well as speak about possible solutions to the problems that face our workers and communities.        Rep. Payne speaks to Machinists' union (8/6/2019)    Legislation:  I have introduced or signed on to support several legislative initiatives. I wanted to give you a brief introduction to just a few of those measures.    Payment Choice: Giving residents the choice to pay in cash  Recently, I heard that more businesses are trying to get rid of cash as a form of payment for goods and services. Companies say it will make it easier for consumers. In truth, it will make it easier for companies to secure transactions, reduce the risk of crime, and speed up the process to serve more customers and make more money.  While I applaud the innovation behind these technological advances, we must remember that they aren’t always good for everyone. Nearly 25 percent of Americans don’t have access to digital forms of payments, including credit or debit cards. If we eliminate cash payments, we eliminate the only option for these consumers, including seniors and low-income residents, to buy their groceries and pay for other goods and services.    That is why I teamed with fellow New Jersey delegation member Rep. Chris Smith to introduce the “Payment Choice Act of 2019.” This bill would protect cash as a form of payment and require retailers to give consumers the choice to pay with credit cards, debit cards, or cash. The New Jersey State Legislature passed a similar law this year. I want consumers here and across the country to still be able to pay for items “the old-fashioned way.”  Return of Local and State Tax Deductions: Returning tax money to Americans  President Trump put a limit on the amount of state and local taxes that workers could deduct from their federal income tax.  His Tax Cuts and Jobs Act caps the State and Local Tax deduction, also known as the SALT deduction, to $10,000. Previously, there was no cap on deductions.  This is a major concern for me because it hit the middle and lower class residents in our community the hardest.  My constituents averaged more than $17,000 in SALT deductions last year.  On average, this current law will deny taxpayers an additional $7,000 per year in deductions.  I am working to repeal it, so the hard-working families of our 10th District can get that money back in their pockets.  Donald Payne, Sr. Colorectal Cancer Detection Act: Giving patients more payment options for treatment  My father, Congressman Donald M. Payne, Sr., died of colorectal cancer. Even though his cancer is a preventable disease, his cancer screening happened too late to catch it in time. Sadly, his case was not unique.        Donald Payne, Sr.    One out of every four Americans between the ages of 50 and 75 fail to get screened for this deadly disease. African-American men are particularly vulnerable. They are 20 percent more likely to get colorectal cancer and 45 percent more likely to die from it than white men. The American Cancer Society recently found that incidences and deaths due to colorectal cancer are even increasing in people younger than 50.  On June 4th, I testified before the House Ways and Means Committee about my bill, The Donald Payne, Sr. Colorectal Cancer Detection Act, because it would address this issue directly. Until recently, there were only two methods for colorectal cancer screening: colonoscopy and stool tests. Fortunately, there is a new test that can detect the disease with a simple blood draw. It can be done during a lunch hour in any facility that can draw blood. This test has the potential to significantly increase screening and save countless lives.  Another big issue with colon cancer is how to pay to fight it. Right now, Medicare will cover the screening, but not the treatment. If doctors find cancer cells and a growth, they must wait until the patient recovers from the screening to ask if they want the cancer removed. My bill would provide Medicare coverage for all FDA-approved, blood-based tests for colorectal cancer screening and the treatment, if cancer is found. That way we can prevent what happened to my father from happening to other fathers nationwide.  SAFE Act of 2019: Making our elections safer and easier for voters  Nothing is more important to democracy than faith in the electoral system. This is why Russia is so desperate to hack and infiltrate our social media. They want to create distrust in our elections and our democracy.  I signed on to the SAFE Act to strengthen the security of our elections and the trust in our democracy. The Act will address election security concerns through grant programs and requirements for voting systems and paper ballots. Thanks to this act, the Election Assistance Commission will have several new responsibilities. It must award grants to states to replace certain voting systems, carry out voting system security improvements, find the best way to design a ballot, write instructions for how to use that ballot, and test the ease of use for future ballots. I believe these actions will make our elections safer and easier for voters.  Aviation Humanitarian Crisis Act of 2019: Denying airlines the right to overcharge passengers during a crisis  In September, I introduced the Aviation Humanitarian Crisis Act of 2019, legislation to prevent airplane ticket price gouging before and after disasters. Climate change has increased the number of natural disasters dramatically. When they hit, area residents have few options available to take shelter and find safety, particularly when they are stuck on an island. During the time of Hurricane Maria, major airlines significantly raised their ticket prices in Puerto Rico. Many citizens who tried to evacuate before or after that disaster were trapped because they couldn’t afford the outrageous costs. My bill would prevent such airline abuse in the future for all Americans.  Raise the Wage Act of 2019: Giving minimum wage workers the raise they deserve  We need to give our workers a raise to show our appreciation for the hard work and effort they put in every day.  I co-sponsored this legislation because it would increase the federal minimum wage for regular employees over a seven-year period, tipped employees, and newly hired employees who are under the age of 20 years old.  The bill would increase the minimum wage every year for six years until it reached $15 per hour for regular employees.  It would provide other increases for disabled employees as well as employees who receive tips as a substantial portion of their wages.  A pay raise for these workers is long overdue.  This legislation would give employees a living wage and increase economic opportunities in their communities.         Gateway Project Update: Pushing to rebuild bridges and tunnels connecting New York and New Jersey        Gateway construction area    In September, the Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure held a hearing on federal grants for state infrastructure projects. The Gateway Program, which will replace decaying bridges and tunnels connecting New Jersey and New York, is the most critical infrastructure project in the country. The federal government promised to fund half of the total cost of the project and then began to backtrack on that promise.  That agreement should be honored. During the hearing, I questioned the acting Administrator of the Federal Transit Administration on why they are holding up federal funding for the Portal North Bridge project when it is ready to begin.  We need this project funded and these improvements made immediately.  Constituent Correspondence: Responding to Constituent Concerns  The thousands of letters I receive from constituents are extremely important to me.  During the time period from January 3 to September 30, 2019, I received 18,860 letters from constituents throughout the district about a variety of topics.      Constituent Letters based on City of Origin    I appreciate your letters and your concerns about issues that affect our district.  The most popular subjects were support for impeaching President Trump, support for the Dreamers and Promise Act, support for gun control regulation, support for the Climate Action Now Act, support for legislation to support the Green New Deal, support for the Equality Act, support for a ban on toxic pesticides, support for the Social Security Fairness Act, support for stronger rules against robocalls, and support for the Saving America's Pollinators Act.     In closing, it has been a busy time for legislative and district activities.  These are but a few of the actions I’ve taken during the last few months to improve the health and prosperity of all my constituents. I hope you are having a great Fall and let me know how I can be of service in the future.  Sincerely, Donald M. Payne, Jr. Member of Congress                                Join the conversation.                   OFFICE LOCATIONS         Washington, DC 103 Cannon HOBWashington, D.C. 20515Tel: (202) 225-3436Fax: (202) 225-4160 Newark  LeRoy Smith Public Safety Bldg.60 Nelson Place, 14th FloorNewark, NJ 07102Tel: (973) 645-3213Fax: (973) 645-5902 Jersey City 253 Martin Luther King Dr.Jersey City, NJ 07305Tel: (201) 369-0392Fax: (201) 369-0395 Hillside 1455 Liberty AvenueHillside, NJ 07205Tel: (862) 229-2994Fax: (862) 255-2941             Unsubscribe |

Despite the chaos swirling around Washington, Rep. Lee understands that drug prices are still too high, education is still unaffordable, and many are still struggling to make ends meet. From southern Nevada to DC, Rep. Lee remains committed to helping find solutions to these tough problems.  Weekly Recap  Last Thursday, Rep. Lee--who is Chairwoman of the House Veterans' Affairs Subcommittee on Technology Modernization--oversaw a hearing to hold the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) accountable for its blatant ineffectiveness in implementing a modernized patient scheduling system. Prolonged appointment scheduling and wait times at VA health facilities remain long-standing issues within the VA, and this is in part due to the VA’s confusing and outdated patient appointment scheduling system. As the member of Congress in charge of overseeing VA's electronic health care system and much of their duty to deliver health care to military veterans, Chairwoman Lee refuses to waiver in holding VA accountable for the implementation of the scheduling system, and their assurance that taxpayer dollars will be used responsibly. Learn more about the hearing .     Later that day, Rep. Lee and Senator Dick Durbin (Ill.) introduced legislation to overturn Education Secretary Betsy DeVos’s rewritten borrower defense rule that gutted essential protections for student borrowers and taxpayers. The original 2016 Borrower Defense Rule was a commonsense policy meant to level the playing field between students and the predatory colleges taking advantage of them. But Secretary DeVos’s new rule makes the process of applying for and granting borrower defense forgiveness unnecessarily difficult and burdensome for the students who we are supposed to be protecting.  The original Borrower Defense Rule was projected to secure $17 billion in relief for defrauded students by 2020. According to the Department of Education’s own estimates, the new DeVos rule is expected to garner only a fraction of that. Read more about the resolution .  On Friday, Reps. Lee and Katie Porter (Calif.-45) sent a letter to the House Appropriations Committee requesting support for increased investment in Graduate Medical Education (GME) programs in the final Fiscal Year 2020 budget. Rep. Lee is committed to addressing southern Nevada’s doctor shortage, which has reached crisis levels in recent years. Increasing GME slots will help increase opportunities for medical students and young doctors, and give them chances to set down roots for their careers in southern Nevada. Read the full letter .  In the District    This weekend, Rep. Lee joined the southern Nevada community to celebrate Nevada's 3rd Annual Public Lands Day.     Rep. Lee rolled up her sleeves and grabbed a shovel to help Kesterson Elementary build their school garden. The garden build was led by Green Our Planet, an organization that runs the largest school garden program in the country.   Coming Up  Rep. Lee will be joined by House Education and Labor Committee Chairman Bobby Scott ofVirginia, to deliver remarks at the Nevada State College 'State of Higher Education' event. They will discuss higher education access and affordability, education policies for minority students, and higher education in southern Nevada. RSVP HERE if you would like to attend! Details below.  Bill and Serving Florida's 6th District

Despite the constant fighting over impeachment that you see on television every day, which is such a distraction from the major reforms needed in this country, my team and I have been making progress in Congress for you:   My district staff held a Service Academy Day, where prospective students from all over our community came to learn about the process of applying to one of our nation's military service academies.  The House Science, Space and Technology committee passed my bill to improve opportunities in STEM education for minorities. The full House passed a bill with one of my amendments to improve Florida's water quality. The “casework corner” section of this newsletter highlights the continued assistance our team provides members of our community.  Please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page and following me on Twitter, Youtube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if my team or I can ever be of service. In service,      Michael Waltz  SERVICE ACADEMY DAY: My office recently held a very successful Service Academy Day. Young students came from all over our community to learn about the process of applying to and attending one of our nation's military service academies. I attended the Virginia Military Institute and I'm so grateful for all the lessons I learned there. If you are a high school Junior and are interested in attending a service academy but missed this event, please call my office for information about applying!       Student cadet Color Guard stands at attention for the National Anthem   A student cadet speaks with a representative from West Point   IMPROVING STEM OPPORTUNITIES FOR MINORITIES: Last Wednesday, the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology unanimously passed a bill I sponsored with Rep. Eddie Bernice Johnson (D-Texas) to improve STEM opportunities for minority students at minority-serving institutions. This bill would increase the capacity for students in STEM fields and build research competitiveness so minority students will be equipped with the tools they need to enter the STEM workforce. Minorities make up 27 percent of the population but are severely underrepresented in STEM fields, only accounting for 11 percent of the workforce. STEM fields are huge drivers in our economy and it’s critical we expand the talent pool to fill STEM jobs.This bill can now head to the House floor for a full vote and I’m looking forward to it passing! Click below to watch me discuss this bill in our committee hearing:     PROTECTING FLORIDA'S WATERWAYS: As Floridians, we all know how important clean water is to our way of life and to our economy. I’m proud to announce that last week, the House passed one of my amendments as part of the first-ever federal action plan to combat harmful algal blooms in Florida. My amendment to include regional coastal waters like the Indian River Lagoon as part of this protection was included in this bill. I’m thankful for the leadership of Rep. Brian Mast and Sen. Marco Rubio, who sponsored these bills. Gov. Ron DeSantis has also made clean water and resiliency a priority in our state. We are all committed to facing these challenges to our waterways and this bill will be an important step to ensuring our waterways stay clean.   Click below to watch me debate this bill on the House floor:        CASEWORK CORNER: Tony, a former Army serviceman, reached out to our office to seek help after his wife and step-daughter's immigration benefits were denied. After working with our caseworkers, Tony’s step-daughter received her Green Card and his wife had her naturalization interview and naturalization ceremony at the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services this week! Glad we could help! If you are struggling to navigate the federal bureaucracy and need help, please contact my office at (386) 302-0442!   Tony with his wife, step-daughter and granddaughter   As a reminder, please follow my daily work on social media by liking my Facebook page, and following me on Twitter, YouTube and Instagram. As always, feel free to reach out to my offices in Florida or Washington, D.C. if we can ever be of service. Thanks for reading!                Washington, DC 216 Cannon House Office BuildingWashington, DC 20515Phone: (202) 225-2706 Deland Office 120 South Florida Ave.Suite 324Deland, FL 32720Phone: (386) 279-0707 Palm Coast Office 31 Lupi CourtSuite 130Palm Coast, FL 32137Phone: (386)-302-0442 Port Orange Office Port Orange City Hall1000 City Center Circle2nd FloorPort Orange, FL 32129Phone: (386) 238-9711          Unsubscribe | Privacy  Open in browser window     Open plain text version
